docs.lead_paragraph: One day before a rally planned by drivers demanding lower insurance rates, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would temporarily abandon her proposal to offer motorists less coverage for lower rates and move ahead with other parts of her plan certain to win quick approval in the Legislature. To help defuse anger among voters frustrated by the nation's highest auto insurance bills, Governor Whitman and Republican legislative leaders said they would end automatic annual insurance-rate increases and surcharges for drivers ticketed for traffic violations.

headline.main: Whitman Puts Hold on Plan For Insurance

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman will temporarily abandon her proposal to offer New Jersey motorists less coverage for lower rates and move ahead with other parts of her automobile-insurance plan that are certain to win quick approval in Legislature (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HFS Inc. is in talks to buy the Signature Group, a direct-marketing business, from the Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation for more than $1 billion in cash, a person familiar with the talks said yesterday. HFS entered the talks last year but is not likely to announce any proposed acquisition of the Signature Group for at least two months, the person said. Montgomery Ward said on April 1 that it might sell ''certain operating units'' to help pay off some or all of its debt, $1 billion of which is due in August.

headline.main: HFS Is Said to Bid For Montgomery Ward Unit

docs.lead_paragraph: Two Bergen County chiropractors agreed to settle charges that they bilked state-run auto insurance pools of more than $12 million by performing meaningless tests and procedures, the Attorney General's office said yesterday. The chiropractors, Steven Verchow of Paramus and Alexander Kuntzevich of Oradell, filed $40 million in bogus claims that had not been paid yet, officials said.
docs.abstract: Bergen County, NJ, chiropractors Steven Verchow and Alexander Kuntzevich agree to settle charges that they bilked state-run auto insurance pools of more than $12 million by performing meaningless tests and procedures (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)
